'''Jason Thomas Mraz''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|r|æ|z}}; born June 23, 1977) is an American guitarist, singer and songwriter. He rose to prominence with the release of his debut studio album, ''[[Waiting for My Rocket to Come]]'' (2002), which spawned the single "[[The Remedy (I Won't Worry)]]", that reached the top 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart.<ref name="charthistory">[http://www.billboard.com/artist/304259/jason-mraz/chart Jason Mraz: Chart History], The Hot 100, ''Billboard''. Retrieved May 25, 2014.</ref> His next two studio albums, ''[[Mr. A-Z]]'' (2005), and ''[[We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things.]]'' (2008), peaked in the top five on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]; with the latter album spawning the [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] winning singles "[[Make It Mine]]", and "[[Lucky (Jason Mraz and Colbie Caillat song)|Lucky]]" with [[Colbie Caillat]]. 

The album's lead single "[[I'm Yours (Jason Mraz song)|I'm Yours]]", reached the top ten on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, while spending a then-record 76 weeks on the Hot 100, and was certified [[Diamond Certified|Diamond]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).<ref>[https://jasonmraz.com/im-yours-certified-diamond-by-the-riaa/ "I'm Yours" Certified Diamond by the RIAA | Jason Mraz] Jason Mraz, June 27, 2019.</ref> His fourth album, ''[[Love Is a Four Letter Word (album)|Love Is a Four Letter Word]]'' (2012), peaked at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200, becoming his highest-charting album to date, and spawned the single "[[I Won't Give Up]]", which became his second top ten on the Hot 100.

Along with receiving two Grammy Award wins, Mraz is also the recipient of two [[Teen Choice Awards]], a [[People's Choice Award]] and the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame|Hal David Songwriters Hall of Fame Award]]. As of July 2014, Mraz has sold over seven million albums,<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/jason-mraz-my-music-says-everything-will-be-ok/ "Jason Mraz: My music says 'Everything will be OK',"] [[CBS News]], July 13, 2014.</ref> and over 11.5 million in digital singles.<ref>[https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinum.php?content_selector=top-artists-digital-singles "Top Artists (Digital Singles),"] [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. Accessed July 15, 2014.</ref> His musical style, from rhythmic feeling to his use of nylon string guitars, has been heavily influenced by [[Brazilian music]].<ref>Rodgers, Jeffrey Pepper. [https://search.proquest.com/docview/821022513 "JASON MRAZ."] Acoustic Guitar 10 2010: 48–53.</ref><ref>[https://search.proquest.com/docview/1082917 "Upbeat: Jason Mraz Believes in Magic."] International Musician 10 2006: 25.</ref> 

==Early life==
Mraz was born and raised in [[Mechanicsville, Virginia]].<ref name="kbellows">Keith Bellows, [http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/traveler-magazine/one-on-one/jason-mraz/ "Traveling Troubadour,"] ''[[National Geographic Traveler]]'', March 2011.</ref> He is of [[Czech people|Czech]] descent through his grandfather, who moved to the United States from [[Austria-Hungary]] in 1915.<ref name="sdm080608">{{Cite news | first = Tom | last = Blair | url = http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/San-Diego-Magazine/November-2008/Jason-Mraz/ | title = Dialogue: Jason Mraz | date = November 2008 | work = San Diego Magazine | access-date = February 6, 2009 | archive-date = August 10, 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140810063900/http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/San-Diego-Magazine/November-2008/Jason-Mraz/ | url-status = dead }}</ref> His surname is {{langnf||Czech|frost}}<ref name="sdm080608"/> ({{lang|cs|[[wiktionary:mráz|mráz]]}}, {{IPA-cs|ˈmraːz|}}). His parents, Tom (Tomáš {{IPA-cs|tomaːʃ|}}) Mraz and June Tomes, divorced when he was five years old, leaving Mraz to live with his father while his sister lived with his mother.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Friend|first=David|title=Coffee Shop Boy Goes Global: Jason Mraz Talks About the Past & Present|url=http://www.jupiter2.com/eo/eo_exclusive/interviews/jason_mraz.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050226100842/http://www.jupiter2.com/eo/eo_exclusive/interviews/jason_mraz.html|archive-date=26 February 2005|access-date=23 December 2021}}</ref> His father is a postal worker, and his mother is vice president at a branch of [[Bank of America]].<ref name= allthat>Ruggieri, Melissa (October 5, 2003). "All That Mraz: After Breaking Big, Musician Comes Home to His Family, and Maybe Brunswick Stew". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch'' (Richmond, Virginia). p. H1.</ref>

Mraz's first concert was [[Young MC]], the rapper known for ''[[Bust a Move (song)|"Bust a Move]]."''<ref name=":1"/>

While attending [[Lee-Davis High School]], Mraz was a member of the [[cheerleading]] squad, [[Choir|school chorus]], and drama club. He starred as [[Joseph (Genesis)|Joseph]] in ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]]'' and as [[Snoopy]] in a play about the [[Peanuts]] characters.<ref>Patterson, Kristin (July 26, 1992). "Finding Right Joseph Was Battle Against Odds". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch''. p. N3.</ref><ref>Johnson, Ophelia (July 29, 1992). "Adding a Sparc of Color to Dogwood Dell Program". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch''. p. C1.</ref><ref>Andersen, Laurie (March 10, 1993). "Theme Sets Tone for Karaoke Parties: Lee-Davis Students to Present 'Snoopy!'". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch''. p. H2.</ref> Mraz graduated in 1995.<ref>"780 Seniors Earn Diplomas". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch''. June 14, 1995. p. J8.</ref> 

During this period of his life, he struggled with his sexuality at times, wondering if he was gay.<ref name=":1"/>

Mraz credits an early girlfriend as being one of the influences that drove him to songwriting. She encouraged him to write his thoughts on paper which helped him get "all of the voices in my head to shut up" and "become something I could follow."<ref name=":1"/>

After high school, Mraz attended the [[American Musical and Dramatic Academy]] in [[New York City]] for about a year and a half, originally to work in musical theater.<ref name="himnow">Ruggieri, Melissa (November 27, 2002). "Jason Mraz Home, and Just Look at Him Now". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch'' (Richmond, Virginia). p. E1.</ref> When his roommates played guitar he would provide the vocals.<ref name=":1"/> Eventually, a friend gave him a guitar that was about to be thrown away and Mraz learned to play and write his own music.<ref name="himnow" /><ref>Yadegaran, Jessica (May 16, 2003). "In the Mood for Mraz: Jason Mraz Opened for Jewel's Local Performance Last Year This Time, He's the Star of the Show". ''The Tribune'' (San Luis Obispo, California). p. 14.</ref> <ref>White, Sue (October 23, 2003). "Experience builds music career". ''Saginaw News'' (Saginaw, Michigan). p. 3D.</ref> 

Mraz moved to the [[Shockoe Bottom]] neighborhood of [[Richmond, Virginia]], where he took a series of odd jobs, including elementary-school janitor, and joined the Ashland Stage Company.<ref>Deeds, Michael (January 17, 2003). "Singer Mraz ditches mop, waits for his 'Rocket to Come'". ''The Idaho Statesman'' (Boise, Idaho). p. 3.</ref><ref name="himnow" /><ref name="jtupponce">Joan Tupponce, [http://www.richmondmagazine.com/articles/jason-mraz-03-24-2010.html "Jason Mraz,"] ''Richmond Magazine'', March 24, 2010.</ref><ref>Proctor, Roy (November 30, 1998). "'Celebration' A Revelation". ''Richmond Times-Dispatch''. p. E5.</ref> Mraz then enrolled at [[Longwood University]] in [[Farmville, Virginia]], on a scholarship.<ref name="himnow" /> Instead of attending classes, he headed west on a road trip that ultimately brought him to [[San Diego]], where he decided to stay.<ref name="sdm080608" /><ref name="jtupponce" />

==Music career==
===Coffee house beginnings (2000–01)===
Soon after moving to San Diego in 1999, Mraz became a roadie for the band [[Michael Andrews (musician)|Elgin Park]]. He met future band member Toca Rivera at Java Joe's, a coffee house in the [[Ocean Beach, San Diego|Ocean Beach]] neighborhood of San Diego known for being formative in the careers of Jewel and Steve Poltz.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Jewel, Jason Mraz, Steve Poltz started at Java Joe's {{!}} San Diego Reader|url=https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/oct/04/tin-fork-jewel-jason-mraz-steve-poltz-java-joes/|access-date=2021-12-24|website=Sandiegoreader.com|language=en}}</ref> Mraz performed once a week for nearly three years, building a following in San Diego and online.<ref>Garin, Nina (December 6, 2001). "Like other local greats, Jason Mraz hopes to find his cup runneth over with success". ''The San Diego Union-Tribune''.</ref><ref name="sdm080608"/><ref name="jtupponce"/> 

Mraz released ''A Jason Mraz Demonstration'' in 1999, ''From the Cutting Room Floor'' and ''Oh Love, In Sadness (The E Minor EP in F)'' in 2001, which were self-released and pressed in a limited number of copies. In 2001, Mraz released the live acoustic album ''[[Live at Java Joe's]],'' performing with percussionist Rivera and bassist Ian Sheridan. The album featured Mraz's freelancing vocal style and several songs he would later re-release, including "1000 Things", "You and I Both" and "Halfway Home." The album was made available to download on [[iTunes]] on March 11, 2008, under the title ''[[Jason Mraz: Live & Acoustic 2001]]''. Mraz returned to perform at Java Joe's for the 15th anniversary of the album on January 29, 2016.<ref>Lothspeich, Dustin (January 31, 2016). "A lot can happen in 15 years -- just ask Jason Mraz." ''NBC 7 San Diego''.</ref> Mraz' last self-released album was ''Sold Out (In Stereo)'' on March 21, 2002.

===''Waiting for My Rocket to Come'' (2002–04)===
In late 2001, Mraz signed a recording contract with [[Elektra Records]] and moved to [[Los Angeles]].<ref>Garin, Nina (January 3, 2002). "Just one more list: Local music scene has its top sounds too". ''the San Diego Union-Tribune''.</ref><ref name="jtupponce"/> In 2002, he opened for [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]] on her tour.<ref>Bass, Debra D. (September 15, 2002). "Jewel Tour Shows What's Under the Label". ''The Press Democrat'' (Santa Rosa, California). p. Q17.</ref> On October 15, 2002, Mraz released his first major label debut album, ''[[Waiting for My Rocket to Come]]'', which peaked at number 55 on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/61899/now-19-still-no-1-on-album-chart "’NOW 19’ Still No. 1 On Album Chart,"] ''Billboard''. Retrieved May 25, 2014.</ref> The first single, "You & I Both," was sent to radio stations time for the album's release, but received minimal airplay, which led Elektra to reconsider whether a mid-tempo song was the right way to introduce Mraz.<ref name=":1"/>

In early 2003, the label took a new approach with the more upbeat "[[The Remedy (I Won't Worry)]]." The track was co-written by music production team [[The Matrix (production team)|The Matrix]], and became Mraz's first top-40 single on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, peaking at number 15, becoming one of the biggest songs of 2003.<ref name="charthistory" /> The song was inspired by a high school friend who was diagnosed with cancer.<ref name="jtupponce" /> At the time of the album's release, Mraz said that he did not like "The Remedy (I Won't Worry)" and had not wanted it on the album because it had started as a special and experimental song and the record label had "chalked up this chorus".<ref name="belt">Garin, Nina (October 10, 2002). "Coffee Break: With all those Java Joe's gigs under his belt, Jason Mraz tests the recording waters". ''The San Diego Union-Tribune''.</ref> The day after the album's release, Mraz played on "[[The Late Late Show With Craig Kilborn]]".<ref>McDonough, Kevin (October 16, 2002). "Practice, practice, practice for Carnegie opening". ''Chattanooga Times Free Press'' (Chattanooga, Tennessee). p. 46.</ref> 

Elektra would return to "You & I Both" a second time, shooting a music video and re-releasing it as the second official single.

On May 19, 2005, ''Waiting for My Rocket to Come'' was certified Platinum, for selling 1 million units.<ref name="riaagoldplatinum">[https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?content_selector=gold-platinum-searchable-database Searchable Database] (search under: Jason Mraz), RIAA. Accessed July 15, 2014.</ref>

Mraz opened for [[Tracy Chapman]] in 2003 at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London.<ref>Paul Woloszyn, [http://www.musicomh.com/features/interviews/interview-jason-mraz "Interview – Jason Mraz,"] [[musicOMH]], August 3, 2005.</ref> In 2004, while on tour, Mraz released a live album with an accompanying DVD, ''[[Tonight, Not Again: Jason Mraz Live at the Eagles Ballroom]]''. He performed with his touring band, including drummer Adam King, Rivera, Sheridan and keyboardist Eric Hinojosa, along with a guest appearance from [[Blues Traveler]] frontman [[John Popper]].<ref>Ansell Regalado, [http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2004-12-24/entertainment/0412210826_1_jason-mraz-songs-music "Tonight’s A Treat For Mraz’s Fans,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208194302/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2004-12-24/entertainment/0412210826_1_jason-mraz-songs-music |date=December 8, 2013 }} ''[[Sun-Sentinel]]'', December 24, 2004.</ref>

===''Mr. A–Z'' (2005–08)===
On July 26, 2005, Mraz released his second major label album, ''[[Mr. A–Z]]'', produced by [[Steve Lillywhite]] for [[Atlantic Records]]. The album's lead single, "Wordplay", was produced by [[Kevin Kadish]],<ref name="billboardalanis">[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/63197/mraz-nails-down-new-album-alanis-dates "Mraz Nails Down New Album, Alanis Dates,"] ''Billboard''. Retrieved May 25, 2014.</ref> and entered the ''Billboard'' 200 at number 5.<ref name="kcaulfield">Keith Caulfield, [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/492829/jason-mraz-vs-lionel-richie-for-no-1-album-next-week "Jason Mraz Vs. Lionel Richie For No. 1 Album Next Week,"] ''Billboard'', April 19, 2012.</ref> The album earned a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical, while Lillywhite received a nomination for Producer of the Year.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,178108,00.html | title = Fast Facts: 48th Annual Grammy Nominees | date = December 8, 2005 | access-date = July 1, 2007 | publisher = Fox News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070530033823/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,178108,00.html |archive-date=May 30, 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

Mraz began a long-running tour in support of ''Mr. A–Z'' at the [[San Diego Music Awards]] on September 12, 2005. The tour featured several opening acts, including [[Bushwalla]] and [[Tristan Prettyman]], with whom he had written the duet "Shy That Way" in 2002.<ref>{{cite web | last = Jacobs | first = Jay S | year = 2005 | url = http://www.popentertainment.com/tristanprettyman.htm | title = Tristan Prettyman Rides the Crest | access-date = July 1, 2007 |url-status=dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070703011719/http://www.popentertainment.com/tristanprettyman.htm | archive-date = July 3, 2007}}</ref> Mraz opened for [[Alanis Morissette]] during her 2005 ''[[Jagged Little Pill]] Acoustic'' tour,<ref name="billboardalanis"/> and for the [[Rolling Stones]] on five dates during their 2005–06 world tour.<ref name="sdm080608"/> In March 2006, he performed in [[Singapore]] as part of the annual [[Mosaic Music Festival]].<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/sunny-sentiments-from-jason-mraz | title = Sunny sentiments from Jason Mraz | date = October 29, 2018 | website = The Straits Times | language = en|access-date=June 5, 2019}}</ref> That May, he toured mostly small venues and music festivals in the U.S., along with a few shows in the United Kingdom and Ireland where he supported James Blunt <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.jamesblunt.com/cgi-bin/teemz/teemz.cgi?board=_master&action=opentopic&forum=James_Blunt__Live_2&topic=1476|title=JAMES BLUNT - Message Board : James Blunt - Live : ABERDEEN, AECC - Sat 25th Feb 2006|website=Archive.jamesblunt.com|access-date=December 26, 2021}}</ref> The tour included a May 6, 2006 acoustic show with [[P.O.D.]], [[Better Than Ezra]], [[Live (band)|Live]], and [[The Presidents of the United States of America (band)|The Presidents of the United States of America]]. Mraz was featured as a headlining guest of [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis's]] annual [[Fair St. Louis]] and performed a free concert at the base of the [[Gateway Arch]] on July 1, 2006. During this time, Mraz was also the opening act at several dates for [[Rob Thomas (musician)|Rob Thomas]]' [[Something to Be Tour]].

[[File:Jason Mraz Foxwood May 2006 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Jason Mraz performs at [[Foxwoods Resort Casino]] in Ledyard, Connecticut on May 17, 2006.]]
In 2005, Mraz was one of many singers featured in the fall advertisement campaign for [[The Gap (clothing retailer)|The Gap]] entitled "Favorites", singing a cover of [[Bob Marley]]'s "[[One Love (Bob Marley song)|One Love]]".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.softpedia.com/news/GAP-Favorites-Alanis-Morissette-Joss-Stone-Destiny-s-Child-singer-Michelle-Williams-and-Keith-Urban-5662.shtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051124092301/http://news.softpedia.com/news/GAP-Favorites-Alanis-Morissette-Joss-Stone-Destiny-s-Child-singer-Michelle-Williams-and-Keith-Urban-5662.shtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 24, 2005 | title = GAP Favorites Alanis Morissette, Jos Stone, Destiny's Child sing Michelle Williams and Keith Urban | date = July 31, 2005}}</ref> 2006 saw the release of ''Selections for Friends'', the live, online-only album recorded during the Songs for Friends Tour. In 2007, "The Beauty in Ugly", an earlier track penned by Mraz originally titled "Plain Jane", was rewritten for the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television show ''[[Ugly Betty]]''. The song was featured as a part of ABC's "Be Ugly in '07" campaign. Also that year, on ''[[American Idol]]'', contestant [[Chris Richardson]] performed a cover of Mraz's "[[Geek in the Pink]]".<ref>Kari Livingston, [https://web.archive.org/web/20140729011029/http://voices.yahoo.com/the-case-american-idols-dark-horse-chris-richardson-280218.html "The Case for American Idol’s Dark Horse, Chris Richardson,"] [[Yahoo! Voices]], April 12, 2007.</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=October 2015}}. In a 2006 concert at [[Educational Broadcasting System|EBS]] Space Gonggam, Mraz said in an interview that he was going to make an acoustic album based on his first two albums.

===''We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things.'' (2008–09)===
On May 13, 2008, Mraz released his third studio album, ''[[We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things.]]'' The album debuted at number 3 on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref name="kcaulfield"/> It broke into the top 10 of many international music charts, and reached number 3 in the US and Australia.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://acharts.us/album/35677 | title = Charts–''We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things.'' | publisher = Acharts.us | access-date = August 19, 2012}}</ref> In March 2009, it was certified Platinum for selling 1 million units.<ref name="riaagoldplatinum"/> Mraz has said that the album title was taken from the work of Scottish artist [[David Shrigley]].<ref name="sdm080608"/> Prior to its release, Mraz released three EPs, each with acoustic versions of songs from the album.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1045437/an-ep-extravaganza "An EP Extravaganza,"] ''Billboard''. Retrieved May 25, 2014.</ref>

The lead single, "[[I'm Yours (Jason Mraz song)|I'm Yours]]", was written in August 2004 and originally released as a free acoustic B-side when ''Mr. A-Z'' came out. Through Mraz's live performances of the song, it gained in popularity with fans. When he played it at a festival in Sweden in 2007, the fans were ecstatic and singing along, after which Mraz realized the song's popularity and decided to make it the centerpiece of his next album.<ref name="sdm080608"/> "I'm Yours" became Mraz's first Top 10 hit on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, peaking at #6 on September 20, 2008.<ref>Silvio Pietroluongo, [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267667/black-eyed-peas-jason-mraz-streak-to-hot-100-records "Black Eyed Peas, Jason Mraz Streak To Hot 100 Records,"] ''Billboard'', August 19, 2009.</ref> It ultimately spent 76 weeks on the Hot 100, longer than any other song in the magazine's 51-year history<ref>[http://www.wbur.org/npr/151884542/jason-mraz-a-breakup-record-served-with-a-smile?ft=3&f=151884542 "Jason Mraz: A Breakup Record, Served With A Smile,"] [[NPR]], May 6, 2012.</ref><ref>Daniel Kreps, [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/black-eyed-peas-jason-mraz-make-hot-100-chart-history-20090819 "Black Eyed Peas, Jason Mraz Make Hot 100 History,"] ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', August 19, 2009.</ref> (a record since broken by [[Imagine Dragons]] with "[[Radioactive (Imagine Dragons song)|Radioactive]]" in 2014).<ref>Gary Trust, [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5908530/imagine-dragons-radioactive-breaks-record-for-longest-hot-100-run "Imagine Dragons’ ‘Radioactive’ Breaks Record for Longest Hot 100 Run,"] ''Billboard'', February 19, 2014.</ref> It was a major commercial success in the US, receiving a 7x multi-Platinum certification from the [[RIAA]] for digital sales of over seven million.<ref name="riaagoldplatinum"/> The song was also successful internationally, topping the charts in New Zealand, Norway, Portugal and Sweden, and peaking in the top ten on the charts in 11 other countries.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://acharts.us/song/34437 | title = Charts – "I'm Yours" | publisher = Acharts.us | date = August 12, 2008 | access-date = August 19, 2012}}</ref> By May 2012, it had gained over 125,000,000 hits on [[YouTube]].<ref>[http://metro.co.uk/2012/05/10/jason-mraz-it-took-me-20-minutes-to-write-record-breaking-track-im-yours-420644/ "Jason Mraz: ‘It took me 20 minutes to write record-breaking track I’m Yours’,"] ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'', May 10, 2012.</ref> It was the first song to top the charts in four different radio formats: Mainstream Top 40, Adult Contemporary, Adult Top 40 and Triple A. It also made the Latin Pop and Smooth Jazz charts.<ref>Leah Greenblatt, [http://music-mix.ew.com/2009/08/20/jason-mrazs-im-yours/ "Jason Mraz's 'I'm Yours' smashes Billboard record, remains totally unkillable,"] ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', August 20, 2009.</ref>

===Social activism and philanthropy===
[[File:Jason Mraz at Campo Pequeno 3.jpg|thumb|300px|Jason Mraz in March 2009]]
Mraz is a social activist whose philanthropic efforts span wide-ranging issues, including the environment, human rights and LGBT equality. 

In 2003, after learning one of his beer bottles was listed for sale on eBay, Mraz was inspired to auction off items of his wardrobe online, raising money for the Make a Wish Foundation.<ref name=":1"/>

During early tours, he encouraged his fans to drop off food items as they arrived at the venue, an effort to support local food banks.<ref name=":1"/>

In 2009, he participated in a rescue mission to [[Ghana]] with members of [[Free the Slaves]], a global nonprofit working to liberate children sold into slavery.<ref name="kbellows" /> In 2012, he was featured as the first-ever straight man on the cover of ''[[Instinct (magazine)|Instinct]]'' magazine in recognition of his efforts in support of [[LGBT rights]].<ref>Jeff Katz, [http://instinctmagazine.com/article/cover-guy-jason-mraz "Cover Guy: Jason Mraz,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527212521/http://instinctmagazine.com/article/cover-guy-jason-mraz |date=May 27, 2014 }} ''[[Instinct (magazine)|Instinct]]'', April 2012.</ref>

The Jason Mraz Foundation was established in 2011, with a mission to support charities in the areas of human equality, environment preservation and education.<ref name="artistdirect120511">[http://www.artistdirect.com/entertainment-news/article/jason-mraz-establishes-jason-mraz-foundation/9805362 "Jason Mraz Establishes Jason Mraz Foundation,"] [[Artist Direct]], December 5, 2011.</ref> Organizations supported by the foundation include [[VH1]]'s Save The Music Foundation, [[MusiCares]], [[Surfrider Foundation]], [[Free the Children]], Life Rolls On, the [[School of the Performing Arts in the Richmond Community]], the [[Natural Resources Defense Council]], and the [[True Colors Fund]], which promotes LGBT equality.<ref name="artistdirect120511"/><ref>[http://www.vh1savethemusic.org/celebrity-ambassadors Celebrity Ambassadors] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417104005/http://www.vh1savethemusic.org/celebrity-ambassadors |date=April 17, 2014 }}, VH1 Save the Music Foundation. Retrieved May 25, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sparconline.org/30th/mraz.shtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424025151/http://www.sparconline.org/30th/mraz.shtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 24, 2012 | title = SPARC alum Jason Mraz performs benefit concert as grand finale of SPARC's 30th Anniversary | publisher = sparconline.org | date = December 8, 2012 | access-date = December 8, 2012}}</ref>

Mraz was named the 2010 Surf Industry Manufacturers Association (SIMA) Humanitarian of the Year.<ref>[http://vegetarianstar.com/2010/08/18/jason-mraz-named-2010-sima-humanitarian-of-the-year/ "Jason Mraz Named 2010 SIMA Humanitarian Of The Year,"] ''Vegetarian Star'', August 18, 2010.</ref> He also received the Clean Water Award in 2010 from the Surfrider Foundation, for helping to preserve the world's oceans and beaches.<ref>[http://sandiego.surfrider.org/clean-water-awards-announced "Clean Water Awards Announced!"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527220700/http://sandiego.surfrider.org/clean-water-awards-announced |date=May 27, 2014 }} sandiego.surfrider.org. Retrieved May 25, 2014.</ref> That same year, he teamed up with [[The Nature Conservancy]] and created a PSA using his song "I'm Yours" to raise awareness about the nonprofit organization's efforts to protect the earth.<ref>[http://www.nature.org/photos-and-video/jason-mraz-psa-for-the-nature-conservancy.xml "Jason Mraz PSA for The Nature Conservancy,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527215741/http://www.nature.org/photos-and-video/jason-mraz-psa-for-the-nature-conservancy.xml |date=May 27, 2014 }} The Nature Conservancy. Retrieved Mary 25, 2014.</ref>

On December 16, 2012, Mraz headlined the Milestone Concert in [[Myanmar]] to raise awareness about [[human trafficking]], making him the first foreign artist to play an open-air concert in Myanmar. The concert was organized by [[MTV EXIT]] and held in the People's Square in [[Yangon]], with over 70,000 people in attendance, as part of an initiative to raise awareness about human trafficking in Myanmar.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jason-mraz-tapped-for-milestone-concert-in-myanmar-20121116 "Jason Mraz Tapped for Milestone Concert in Myanmar,"] ''Rolling Stone'', November 16, 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=70,000 Fans Attend MTV EXIT Live in Myanmar Featuring Jason Mraz|url=http://mtvexit.org/worldstage/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130704081832/http://mtvexit.org/worldstage/|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 4, 2013|access-date=May 22, 2013}}</ref> Also in 2012, Mraz spent a week in [[Antarctica]] with a group of environmentalists, scientists and researchers on a mission led by [[Al Gore]], to learn about the effects of climate change.<ref>Jason Mraz, [http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/jason-mraz/jason-mraz-antarctica_b_1459588.html "Global Warming Is No Longer a Future Problem, It’s a Now Event,"] ''[[Huffington Post]]'', April 28, 2012.</ref>

Mraz is a continued supporter of [[WhyHunger]], a grassroots support organization dedicated to fighting hunger and poverty in the United States. The organization was founded by late musician [[Harry Chapin]]  and Radio DJ [[Bill Ayres]] in 1975.<ref>{{Cite press release | url = https://whyhunger.org/category/whyhunger-press-releases/whyhunger-chapin-awards-2018-post-event-release-final/ | title = WhyHunger Honors GRAMMY® Winner Jason Mraz and Fashion Entrepreneur Drew Pizzo at Chapin Awards Gala | date = October 19, 2018 | website = [[World Hunger Year|WhyHunger]] | via = whyhunger.org | access-date = August 29, 2019}}</ref>

On June 19, 2020, Mraz announced he would be donating all profits from his album "[[Look for the Good (album)|Look for the Good]]" to [[Black Lives Matter]] and other organizations working toward equality and justice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/20/us/jason-mraz-donates-look-for-the-good-album-trnd/index.html|title=Jason Mraz is donating all the earnings from his new album to Black Lives Matter and other groups|website=[[CNN]]|date=June 20, 2020 }}</ref>

===Politics===
On October 24, 2019, Mraz endorsed [[Bernie Sanders]] for President in the [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries]] stating, "Bernie is the perfect candidate to follow Trump & continue to shake up the system for the benefit of true American values: Life, Liberty & The Pursuit of Happiness".<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.jasonmraz.com/news/look-for-the-good | title = Look for the Good. | website = Jasonmraz.com}}</ref>
